answers.explanation: Initial OCT methods had poor visualization of the deeper layers of the retina beyond Bruch’s membrane due to scattering of light at the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). EDI-OCT allows for visualization of the deep portions of the choroid, which is implicated in many retinal diseases, and the deep structures of the optic nerve.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-9-4.webp)

Fundus auto-fluorescence imaging was conducted as the findings on the OCT were not in line with the clinical findings on fundus examination. The fundus auto-fluorescence images are shown above: What is the diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
This patient has highly reflective material at the optic disc which coincide with the findings on EDI-OCT of the optic nerve. This material is optic disc drusen (ODD), which is found in 1-2% of the normal population. ODD do not typically cause any significant visual changes, but progressive visual field defects or non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) may rarely occur in their presence. Since ODD cause crowding of the optic nerve, they produce a “disc-at-risk”, which is necessary for NAION.

Fundus auto-fluorescence is useful as mitochondria accumulate in ODD, and these organelles contain large amounts of porphyrins which are otherwise not found at the optic disc. Fundus auto-fluorescence detects fluorophores such as porphyrins, making this test useful for sensitive detection of ODD.
